trans-unit.source: Create a simple experiment in Machine Learning Studio | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Create a simple experiment in Machine Learning Studio | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: A first machine learning tutorial for creating a simple experiment to train and test a linear regression model in Azure Machine Learning Studio.
trans-unit.target: A first machine learning tutorial for creating a simple experiment to train and test a linear regression model in Azure Machine Learning Studio.

trans-unit.source: Machine learning tutorial: Create your first experiment in Azure Machine Learning Studio
trans-unit.target: Machine learning tutorial: Create your first experiment in Azure Machine Learning Studio

trans-unit.source: In this first machine learning tutorial, we'll create a linear regression model that predicts the price of an automobile based on different variables such as make and technical specifications.
trans-unit.target: In this first machine learning tutorial, we'll create a linear regression model that predicts the price of an automobile based on different variables such as make and technical specifications.

trans-unit.source: To do this, we'll use Azure Machine Learning Studio to develop and iterate on a simple predictive analytics experiment.
trans-unit.target: To do this, we'll use Azure Machine Learning Studio to develop and iterate on a simple predictive analytics experiment.

trans-unit.source: A Machine Learning Studio experiment consists of dragging components to a canvas, and connecting them in order to *create a model*, *train the model*, and *score and test the model*.
trans-unit.target: A Machine Learning Studio experiment consists of dragging components to a canvas, and connecting them in order to *create a model*, *train the model*, and *score and test the model*.

trans-unit.source: The experiment uses predictive modeling techniques in the form of Machine Learning Studio modules that ingest data, train a model against it, and apply the model to new data.
trans-unit.target: The experiment uses predictive modeling techniques in the form of Machine Learning Studio modules that ingest data, train a model against it, and apply the model to new data.

trans-unit.source: You can also add modules to preprocess data and select features, split data into training and test sets, and evaluate or cross-validate the quality of your model.
trans-unit.target: You can also add modules to preprocess data and select features, split data into training and test sets, and evaluate or cross-validate the quality of your model.

trans-unit.source: Enter Machine Learning Studio: [https://studio.azureml.net](https://studio.azureml.net), and click the **Get started** button.
trans-unit.target: Enter Machine Learning Studio: [https://studio.azureml.net](https://studio.azureml.net), and click the **Get started** button.

trans-unit.source: You can choose either the Guest Access or sign in with your Microsoft account.
trans-unit.target: You can choose either the Guest Access or sign in with your Microsoft account.

trans-unit.source: For more general information about Machine Learning Studio, see [What is Machine Learning Studio?](machine-learning-what-is-ml-studio.md).
trans-unit.target: For more general information about Machine Learning Studio, see [What is Machine Learning Studio?](machine-learning-what-is-ml-studio.md).

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.TIP] To download and print a diagram that gives an overview of the capabilities of Machine Learning Studio, see [Overview diagram of Azure Machine Learning Studio capabilities](machine-learning-studio-overview-diagram.md).
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.TIP] To download and print a diagram that gives an overview of the capabilities of Machine Learning Studio, see [Overview diagram of Azure Machine Learning Studio capabilities](machine-learning-studio-overview-diagram.md).

trans-unit.source: Five steps to create an experiment
trans-unit.target: Five steps to create an experiment

trans-unit.source: In this machine learning tutorial, you'll follow five basic steps to build an experiment in Machine Learning Studio in order to create, train, and score your model:
trans-unit.target: In this machine learning tutorial, you'll follow five basic steps to build an experiment in Machine Learning Studio in order to create, train, and score your model:

trans-unit.source: Create a model
trans-unit.target: Create a model

trans-unit.source: Train the model
trans-unit.target: Train the model

trans-unit.source: Score and test the model
trans-unit.target: Score and test the model

trans-unit.source: Step 1: Get data
trans-unit.target: Step 1: Get data

trans-unit.source: There are a number of sample datasets included with Machine Learning Studio that you can choose from, and you can import data from many sources.
trans-unit.target: There are a number of sample datasets included with Machine Learning Studio that you can choose from, and you can import data from many sources.

trans-unit.source: For this example, we will use the included sample dataset, **Automobile price data (Raw)**.
trans-unit.target: For this example, we will use the included sample dataset, **Automobile price data (Raw)**.

trans-unit.source: This dataset includes entries for a number of individual automobiles, including information such as make, model, technical specifications, and price.
trans-unit.target: This dataset includes entries for a number of individual automobiles, including information such as make, model, technical specifications, and price.

trans-unit.source: Start a new experiment by clicking **+NEW** at the bottom of the Machine Learning Studio window, select **EXPERIMENT**, and then select **Blank Experiment**.
trans-unit.target: Start a new experiment by clicking **+NEW** at the bottom of the Machine Learning Studio window, select **EXPERIMENT**, and then select **Blank Experiment**.

trans-unit.source: Select the default experiment name at the top of the canvas and rename it to something meaningful, for example, **Automobile price prediction**.
trans-unit.target: Select the default experiment name at the top of the canvas and rename it to something meaningful, for example, **Automobile price prediction**.

trans-unit.source: To the left of the experiment canvas is a palette of datasets and modules.
trans-unit.target: To the left of the experiment canvas is a palette of datasets and modules.

trans-unit.source: Type **automobile** in the Search box at the top of this palette to find the dataset labeled **Automobile price data (Raw)**.
trans-unit.target: Type **automobile** in the Search box at the top of this palette to find the dataset labeled **Automobile price data (Raw)**.

trans-unit.source: ![Palette search][screen1a]
trans-unit.target: ![Palette search][screen1a]

trans-unit.source: Drag the dataset to the experiment canvas.
trans-unit.target: Drag the dataset to the experiment canvas.

trans-unit.source: ![Dataset][screen1]
trans-unit.target: ![Dataset][screen1]

trans-unit.source: To see what this data looks like, click the output port at the bottom of the automobile dataset, and then select **Visualize**.
trans-unit.target: To see what this data looks like, click the output port at the bottom of the automobile dataset, and then select **Visualize**.

trans-unit.source: The variables in the dataset appear as columns, and each instance of an automobile appears as a row.
trans-unit.target: The variables in the dataset appear as columns, and each instance of an automobile appears as a row.

trans-unit.source: The far-right column (column 26 and titled "price") is the target variable we're going to try to predict.
trans-unit.target: The far-right column (column 26 and titled "price") is the target variable we're going to try to predict.

trans-unit.source: ![Dataset visualization][screen1b]
trans-unit.target: ![Dataset visualization][screen1b]

trans-unit.source: Close the visualization window by clicking the "**x**" in the upper-right corner.
trans-unit.target: Close the visualization window by clicking the "**x**" in the upper-right corner.

trans-unit.source: Step 2: Preprocess data
trans-unit.target: Step 2: Preprocess data

trans-unit.source: A dataset usually requires some preprocessing before it can be analyzed.
trans-unit.target: A dataset usually requires some preprocessing before it can be analyzed.

trans-unit.source: You might have noticed the missing values present in the columns of various rows.
trans-unit.target: You might have noticed the missing values present in the columns of various rows.

trans-unit.source: These missing values need to be cleaned so the model can analyze the data correctly.
trans-unit.target: These missing values need to be cleaned so the model can analyze the data correctly.

trans-unit.source: In our case, we'll remove any rows that have missing values.
trans-unit.target: In our case, we'll remove any rows that have missing values.

trans-unit.source: Also, the **normalized-losses** column has a large proportion of missing values, so we'll exclude that column from the model altogether.
trans-unit.target: Also, the **normalized-losses** column has a large proportion of missing values, so we'll exclude that column from the model altogether.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.TIP] Cleaning the missing values from input data is a prerequisite for using most of the modules.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.TIP] Cleaning the missing values from input data is a prerequisite for using most of the modules.

trans-unit.source: First we'll remove the **normalized-losses** column, and then we'll remove any row that has missing data.
trans-unit.target: First we'll remove the **normalized-losses** column, and then we'll remove any row that has missing data.

trans-unit.source: Type **project columns** in the Search box at the top of the module palette to find the [Project Columns][project-columns] module, then drag it to the experiment canvas and connect it to the output port of the **Automobile price data (Raw)** dataset.
trans-unit.target: Type **project columns** in the Search box at the top of the module palette to find the [Project Columns][project-columns] module, then drag it to the experiment canvas and connect it to the output port of the **Automobile price data (Raw)** dataset.

trans-unit.source: This module allows us to select which columns of data we want to include or exclude in the model.
trans-unit.target: This module allows us to select which columns of data we want to include or exclude in the model.

trans-unit.source: Select the [Project Columns][project-columns] module and click **Launch column selector** in the **Properties** pane.
trans-unit.target: Select the [Project Columns][project-columns] module and click **Launch column selector** in the **Properties** pane.

trans-unit.source: Make sure **All columns** is selected in the filter drop-down list, **Begin With**.
trans-unit.target: Make sure **All columns** is selected in the filter drop-down list, **Begin With**.

trans-unit.source: This directs [Project Columns][project-columns] to pass through all the columns (except those we're about to exclude).
trans-unit.target: This directs [Project Columns][project-columns] to pass through all the columns (except those we're about to exclude).

trans-unit.source: In the next row, select **Exclude** and **column names**, and then click inside the text box.
trans-unit.target: In the next row, select **Exclude** and **column names**, and then click inside the text box.

trans-unit.source: A list of columns is displayed.
trans-unit.target: A list of columns is displayed.

trans-unit.source: Select **normalized-losses**, and it will be added to the text box.
trans-unit.target: Select **normalized-losses**, and it will be added to the text box.

trans-unit.source: Click the check mark (OK) button to close the column selector.
trans-unit.target: Click the check mark (OK) button to close the column selector.

trans-unit.source: ![Select columns][screen3]
trans-unit.target: ![Select columns][screen3]

trans-unit.source: The properties pane for **Project Columns** indicates that it will pass through all columns from the dataset except **normalized-losses**.
trans-unit.target: The properties pane for **Project Columns** indicates that it will pass through all columns from the dataset except **normalized-losses**.

trans-unit.source: ![Project Columns properties][screen4]
trans-unit.target: ![Project Columns properties][screen4]

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.TIP] You can add a comment to a module by double-clicking the module and entering text.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.TIP] You can add a comment to a module by double-clicking the module and entering text.

trans-unit.source: This can help you see at a glance what the module is doing in your experiment.
trans-unit.target: This can help you see at a glance what the module is doing in your experiment.

trans-unit.source: In this case, double-click the [Project Columns][project-columns] module and type the comment "Exclude normalized-losses."
trans-unit.target: In this case, double-click the [Project Columns][project-columns] module and type the comment "Exclude normalized-losses."

trans-unit.source: Drag the [Clean Missing Data][clean-missing-data] module to the experiment canvas and connect it to the [Project Columns][project-columns] module.
trans-unit.target: Drag the [Clean Missing Data][clean-missing-data] module to the experiment canvas and connect it to the [Project Columns][project-columns] module.

trans-unit.source: In the **Properties** pane, select **Remove entire row** under **Cleaning mode** to clean the data by removing rows that have missing values.
trans-unit.target: In the **Properties** pane, select **Remove entire row** under **Cleaning mode** to clean the data by removing rows that have missing values.

trans-unit.source: Double-click the module and type the comment "Remove missing value rows."
trans-unit.target: Double-click the module and type the comment "Remove missing value rows."

trans-unit.source: ![Clean Missing Data properties][screen4a]
trans-unit.target: ![Clean Missing Data properties][screen4a]

trans-unit.source: Run the experiment by clicking **RUN** under the experiment canvas.
trans-unit.target: Run the experiment by clicking **RUN** under the experiment canvas.

trans-unit.source: When the experiment is finished, all the modules have a green check mark to indicate that they finished successfully.
trans-unit.target: When the experiment is finished, all the modules have a green check mark to indicate that they finished successfully.

trans-unit.source: Notice also the **Finished running** status in the upper-right corner.
trans-unit.target: Notice also the **Finished running** status in the upper-right corner.

trans-unit.source: ![First experiment run][screen5]
trans-unit.target: ![First experiment run][screen5]

trans-unit.source: All we have done in the experiment to this point is clean the data.
trans-unit.target: All we have done in the experiment to this point is clean the data.

trans-unit.source: If you want to view the cleaned dataset, click the left output port of the [Clean Missing Data][clean-missing-data] module ("Cleaned dataset") and select **Visualize**.
trans-unit.target: If you want to view the cleaned dataset, click the left output port of the [Clean Missing Data][clean-missing-data] module ("Cleaned dataset") and select **Visualize**.

trans-unit.source: Notice that the **normalized-losses** column is no longer included, and there are no missing values.
trans-unit.target: Notice that the **normalized-losses** column is no longer included, and there are no missing values.

trans-unit.source: Now that the data is clean, we're ready to specify what features we're going to use in the predictive model.
trans-unit.target: Now that the data is clean, we're ready to specify what features we're going to use in the predictive model.

trans-unit.source: Step 3: Define features
trans-unit.target: Step 3: Define features

trans-unit.source: In machine learning, *features* are individual measurable properties of something you’re interested in.
trans-unit.target: In machine learning, *features* are individual measurable properties of something you’re interested in.

trans-unit.source: In our dataset, each row represents one automobile, and each column is a feature of that automobile.
trans-unit.target: In our dataset, each row represents one automobile, and each column is a feature of that automobile.

trans-unit.source: Finding a good set of features for creating a predictive model requires experimentation and knowledge about the problem you want to solve.
trans-unit.target: Finding a good set of features for creating a predictive model requires experimentation and knowledge about the problem you want to solve.

trans-unit.source: Some features are better for predicting the target than others.
trans-unit.target: Some features are better for predicting the target than others.

trans-unit.source: Also, some features have a strong correlation with other features (for example, city-mpg versus highway-mpg), so they will not add much new information to the model, and they can be removed.
trans-unit.target: Also, some features have a strong correlation with other features (for example, city-mpg versus highway-mpg), so they will not add much new information to the model, and they can be removed.

trans-unit.source: Let's build a model that uses a subset of the features in our dataset.
trans-unit.target: Let's build a model that uses a subset of the features in our dataset.

trans-unit.source: You can come back and select different features, run the experiment again, and see if you get better results.
trans-unit.target: You can come back and select different features, run the experiment again, and see if you get better results.

trans-unit.source: As a first guess, we'll select the following features (columns) with the [Project Columns][project-columns] module.
trans-unit.target: As a first guess, we'll select the following features (columns) with the [Project Columns][project-columns] module.

trans-unit.source: Note that for training the model, we need to include the *price* value that we're going to predict.
trans-unit.target: Note that for training the model, we need to include the *price* value that we're going to predict.

trans-unit.source: Drag another [Project Columns][project-columns] module to the experiment canvas and connect it to the left output port of the [Clean Missing Data][clean-missing-data] module.
trans-unit.target: Drag another [Project Columns][project-columns] module to the experiment canvas and connect it to the left output port of the [Clean Missing Data][clean-missing-data] module.

trans-unit.source: Double-click the module and type "Select features for prediction."
trans-unit.target: Double-click the module and type "Select features for prediction."

trans-unit.source: Click **Launch column selector** in the **Properties** pane.
trans-unit.target: Click **Launch column selector** in the **Properties** pane.

trans-unit.source: In the column selector, select **No columns** for **Begin With**, and then select **Include** and **column names** in the filter row.
trans-unit.target: In the column selector, select **No columns** for **Begin With**, and then select **Include** and **column names** in the filter row.

trans-unit.source: Enter our list of column names.
trans-unit.target: Enter our list of column names.

trans-unit.source: This directs the module to pass through only columns that we specify.
trans-unit.target: This directs the module to pass through only columns that we specify.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.TIP] Because we've run the experiment, the column definitions for our data have passed from the original dataset through the [Clean Missing Data][clean-missing-data] module.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.TIP] Because we've run the experiment, the column definitions for our data have passed from the original dataset through the [Clean Missing Data][clean-missing-data] module.

trans-unit.source: When you connect [Project Columns][project-columns] to [Clean Missing Data][clean-missing-data], the [Project Columns][project-columns] module becomes aware of the column definitions in our data.
trans-unit.target: When you connect [Project Columns][project-columns] to [Clean Missing Data][clean-missing-data], the [Project Columns][project-columns] module becomes aware of the column definitions in our data.

trans-unit.source: When you click the **column names** box, a list of columns is displayed, and you can select the columns that you want to add to the list.
trans-unit.target: When you click the **column names** box, a list of columns is displayed, and you can select the columns that you want to add to the list.

trans-unit.source: Click the check mark (OK) button.
trans-unit.target: Click the check mark (OK) button.

trans-unit.source: ![Select columns][screen6]
trans-unit.target: ![Select columns][screen6]

trans-unit.source: This produces the dataset that will be used in the learning algorithm in the next steps.
trans-unit.target: This produces the dataset that will be used in the learning algorithm in the next steps.

trans-unit.source: Later, you can return and try again with a different selection of features.
trans-unit.target: Later, you can return and try again with a different selection of features.

trans-unit.source: Step 4: Choose and apply a learning algorithm
trans-unit.target: Step 4: Choose and apply a learning algorithm

trans-unit.source: Now that the data is ready, constructing a predictive model consists of training and testing.
trans-unit.target: Now that the data is ready, constructing a predictive model consists of training and testing.

trans-unit.source: We'll use our data to train the model and then test the model to see how close it's able to predict prices.
trans-unit.target: We'll use our data to train the model and then test the model to see how close it's able to predict prices.

trans-unit.source: *Classification* and *regression* are two types of supervised machine learning techniques.
trans-unit.target: *Classification* and *regression* are two types of supervised machine learning techniques.

trans-unit.source: Classification is used to make a prediction from a defined set of values, such as a color (red, blue, or green).
trans-unit.target: Classification is used to make a prediction from a defined set of values, such as a color (red, blue, or green).

trans-unit.source: Regression is used to make a prediction from a continuous set of values, such as a person's age.
trans-unit.target: Regression is used to make a prediction from a continuous set of values, such as a person's age.

trans-unit.source: We want to predict the price of an automobile, which can be any value, so we'll use a regression model.
trans-unit.target: We want to predict the price of an automobile, which can be any value, so we'll use a regression model.

trans-unit.source: For this example, we'll train a simple *linear regression* model, and in the next step, we'll test it.
trans-unit.target: For this example, we'll train a simple *linear regression* model, and in the next step, we'll test it.

trans-unit.source: We can use our data for both training and testing by splitting it into separate training and testing sets.
trans-unit.target: We can use our data for both training and testing by splitting it into separate training and testing sets.

trans-unit.source: Select and drag the [Split Data][split] module to the experiment canvas and connect it to the output of the last [Project Columns][project-columns] module.
trans-unit.target: Select and drag the [Split Data][split] module to the experiment canvas and connect it to the output of the last [Project Columns][project-columns] module.

trans-unit.source: Set **Fraction of rows in the first output dataset** to 0.75.
trans-unit.target: Set **Fraction of rows in the first output dataset** to 0.75.

trans-unit.source: This way, we'll use 75 percent of the data to train the model, and hold back 25 percent for testing.
trans-unit.target: This way, we'll use 75 percent of the data to train the model, and hold back 25 percent for testing.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.TIP] By changing the **Random seed** parameter, you can produce different random samples for training and testing.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.TIP] By changing the **Random seed** parameter, you can produce different random samples for training and testing.

trans-unit.source: This parameter controls the seeding of the pseudo-random number generator.
trans-unit.target: This parameter controls the seeding of the pseudo-random number generator.

trans-unit.source: Run the experiment.
trans-unit.target: Run the experiment.

trans-unit.source: This allows the [Project Columns][project-columns] and [Split Data][split] modules to pass column definitions to the modules we'll be adding next.
trans-unit.target: This allows the [Project Columns][project-columns] and [Split Data][split] modules to pass column definitions to the modules we'll be adding next.

trans-unit.source: To select the learning algorithm, expand the **Machine Learning** category in the module palette to the left of the canvas, and then expand **Initialize Model**.
trans-unit.target: To select the learning algorithm, expand the **Machine Learning** category in the module palette to the left of the canvas, and then expand **Initialize Model**.

trans-unit.source: This displays several categories of modules that can be used to initialize machine learning algorithms.
trans-unit.target: This displays several categories of modules that can be used to initialize machine learning algorithms.

trans-unit.source: For this experiment, select the [Linear Regression][linear-regression] module under the **Regression** category (you can also find the module by typing "linear regression" in the palette Search box), and drag it to the experiment canvas.
trans-unit.target: For this experiment, select the [Linear Regression][linear-regression] module under the **Regression** category (you can also find the module by typing "linear regression" in the palette Search box), and drag it to the experiment canvas.

trans-unit.source: Find and drag the [Train Model][train-model] module to the experiment canvas.
trans-unit.target: Find and drag the [Train Model][train-model] module to the experiment canvas.

trans-unit.source: Connect the left input port to the output of the [Linear Regression][linear-regression] module.
trans-unit.target: Connect the left input port to the output of the [Linear Regression][linear-regression] module.

trans-unit.source: Connect the right input port to the training data output (left port) of the [Split Data][split] module.
trans-unit.target: Connect the right input port to the training data output (left port) of the [Split Data][split] module.

trans-unit.source: Select the [Train Model][train-model] module, click **Launch column selector** in the **Properties** pane, and then select the **price** column.
trans-unit.target: Select the [Train Model][train-model] module, click **Launch column selector** in the **Properties** pane, and then select the **price** column.

trans-unit.source: This is the value that our model is going to predict.
trans-unit.target: This is the value that our model is going to predict.

trans-unit.source: ![Select "price" column][screen7]
trans-unit.target: ![Select "price" column][screen7]

trans-unit.source: Run the experiment.
trans-unit.target: Run the experiment.

trans-unit.source: The result is a trained regression model that can be used to score new samples to make predictions.
trans-unit.target: The result is a trained regression model that can be used to score new samples to make predictions.

trans-unit.source: ![Applying the machine learning algorithm][screen8]
trans-unit.target: ![Applying the machine learning algorithm][screen8]

trans-unit.source: Step 5: Predict new automobile prices
trans-unit.target: Step 5: Predict new automobile prices

trans-unit.source: Now that we've trained the model using 75 percent of our data, we can use it to score the other 25 percent of the data to see how well our model functions.
trans-unit.target: Now that we've trained the model using 75 percent of our data, we can use it to score the other 25 percent of the data to see how well our model functions.

trans-unit.source: Find and drag the [Score Model][score-model] module to the experiment canvas and connect the left input port to the output of the [Train Model][train-model] module.
trans-unit.target: Find and drag the [Score Model][score-model] module to the experiment canvas and connect the left input port to the output of the [Train Model][train-model] module.

trans-unit.source: Connect the right input port to the test data output (right port) of the [Split Data][split] module.
trans-unit.target: Connect the right input port to the test data output (right port) of the [Split Data][split] module.

trans-unit.source: ![Score Model module][screen8a]
trans-unit.target: ![Score Model module][screen8a]

trans-unit.source: To run the experiment and view the output from the [Score Model][score-model] module, click the output port, and then select **Visualize**.
trans-unit.target: To run the experiment and view the output from the [Score Model][score-model] module, click the output port, and then select **Visualize**.

trans-unit.source: The output shows the predicted values for price and the known values from the test data.
trans-unit.target: The output shows the predicted values for price and the known values from the test data.

trans-unit.source: Finally, to test the quality of the results, select and drag the [Evaluate Model][evaluate-model] module to the experiment canvas, and connect the left input port to the output of the [Score Model][score-model] module.
trans-unit.target: Finally, to test the quality of the results, select and drag the [Evaluate Model][evaluate-model] module to the experiment canvas, and connect the left input port to the output of the [Score Model][score-model] module.

trans-unit.source: (There are two input ports because the [Evaluate Model][evaluate-model] module can be used to compare two models.)
trans-unit.target: (There are two input ports because the [Evaluate Model][evaluate-model] module can be used to compare two models.)

trans-unit.source: Run the experiment.
trans-unit.target: Run the experiment.

trans-unit.source: To view the output from the [Evaluate Model][evaluate-model] module, click the output port, and then select **Visualize**.
trans-unit.target: To view the output from the [Evaluate Model][evaluate-model] module, click the output port, and then select **Visualize**.

trans-unit.source: The following statistics are shown for our model:
trans-unit.target: The following statistics are shown for our model:

trans-unit.source: **Mean Absolute Error** (MAE): The average of absolute errors (an *error* is the difference between the predicted value and the actual value).
trans-unit.target: **Mean Absolute Error** (MAE): The average of absolute errors (an *error* is the difference between the predicted value and the actual value).

trans-unit.source: **Root Mean Squared Error** (RMSE): The square root of the average of squared errors of predictions made on the test dataset.
trans-unit.target: **Root Mean Squared Error** (RMSE): The square root of the average of squared errors of predictions made on the test dataset.

trans-unit.source: **Relative Absolute Error**: The average of absolute errors relative to the absolute difference between actual values and the average of all actual values.
trans-unit.target: **Relative Absolute Error**: The average of absolute errors relative to the absolute difference between actual values and the average of all actual values.

trans-unit.source: **Relative Squared Error**: The average of squared errors relative to the squared difference between the actual values and the average of all actual values.
trans-unit.target: **Relative Squared Error**: The average of squared errors relative to the squared difference between the actual values and the average of all actual values.

trans-unit.source: **Coefficient of Determination**: Also known as the **R squared value**, this is a statistical metric indicating how well a model fits the data.
trans-unit.target: **Coefficient of Determination**: Also known as the **R squared value**, this is a statistical metric indicating how well a model fits the data.

trans-unit.source: For each of the error statistics, smaller is better.
trans-unit.target: For each of the error statistics, smaller is better.

trans-unit.source: A smaller value indicates that the predictions more closely match the actual values.
trans-unit.target: A smaller value indicates that the predictions more closely match the actual values.

trans-unit.source: For **Coefficient of Determination**, the closer its value is to one (1.0), the better the predictions.
trans-unit.target: For **Coefficient of Determination**, the closer its value is to one (1.0), the better the predictions.

trans-unit.source: ![Evaluation results][screen9]
trans-unit.target: ![Evaluation results][screen9]

trans-unit.source: The final experiment should look like this:
trans-unit.target: The final experiment should look like this:

trans-unit.source: ![Machine learning tutorial: Complete linear regression experiment that uses predictive modeling techniques.][screen10]
trans-unit.target: ![Machine learning tutorial: Complete linear regression experiment that uses predictive modeling techniques.][screen10]

trans-unit.source: Next steps
trans-unit.target: Next steps

trans-unit.source: Now that you've completed a first machine learning tutorial and have your experiment set up, you can iterate to try to improve the model.
trans-unit.target: Now that you've completed a first machine learning tutorial and have your experiment set up, you can iterate to try to improve the model.

trans-unit.source: For instance, you can change the features you use in your prediction.
trans-unit.target: For instance, you can change the features you use in your prediction.

trans-unit.source: Or you can modify the properties of the [Linear Regression][linear-regression] algorithm or try a different algorithm altogether.
trans-unit.target: Or you can modify the properties of the [Linear Regression][linear-regression] algorithm or try a different algorithm altogether.

trans-unit.source: You can even add multiple machine learning algorithms to your experiment at one time and compare two by using the [Evaluate Model][evaluate-model] module.
trans-unit.target: You can even add multiple machine learning algorithms to your experiment at one time and compare two by using the [Evaluate Model][evaluate-model] module.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.TIP] Use the **SAVE AS** button under the experiment canvas to copy any iteration of your experiment.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.TIP] Use the **SAVE AS** button under the experiment canvas to copy any iteration of your experiment.

trans-unit.source: You can see all the iterations of your experiment by clicking **VIEW RUN HISTORY** under the canvas.
trans-unit.target: You can see all the iterations of your experiment by clicking **VIEW RUN HISTORY** under the canvas.

trans-unit.source: See [Manage experiment iterations in Azure Machine Learning Studio][runhistory] for more details.
trans-unit.target: See [Manage experiment iterations in Azure Machine Learning Studio][runhistory] for more details.

trans-unit.source: When you're satisfied with your model, you can deploy it as a web service to be used to predict automobile prices by using new data.
trans-unit.target: When you're satisfied with your model, you can deploy it as a web service to be used to predict automobile prices by using new data.

trans-unit.source: See [Deploy an Azure Machine Learning web service][publish] for more details.
trans-unit.target: See [Deploy an Azure Machine Learning web service][publish] for more details.

trans-unit.source: For a more extensive and detailed walkthrough of predictive modeling techniques for creating, training, scoring, and deploying a model, see [Develop a predictive solution by using Azure Machine Learning][walkthrough].
trans-unit.target: For a more extensive and detailed walkthrough of predictive modeling techniques for creating, training, scoring, and deploying a model, see [Develop a predictive solution by using Azure Machine Learning][walkthrough].
